Love cycling but don't know where you are going?  Solution: Bring your GPS with you.  Specifically a TomTom XL310 or similar.  Uses zap straps for attachment.

Download, Slice, Print. No supports, minor bridging, big flat bottom. Got bed stick issues? No problem, warping won't affect the usefulness. Does your printer oversize everything? Whatever, call it an "interferance fit." Scale the model slightly if needed. Please use a strong elastic band or similar to hold the GPS in place, just in case Notes:
-The hole in the bottom is useless due to the angled plug.
-You can stick your TomTom in upside down if you prefer for mounting, but you'll have to take it out to turn it on/off.
-SolidWorks file contains a modeled TomTom 310 XL for making other mounts, please note this thing in your derivation.
Pen or pencil holder. Yes, I know it is awesome, as I am the world's most amazing designer. Feel free to send me a check for 100.00 per download if you wish. Patent pending. hehe

Use "amazing goop" glue to attach to monitor or wherever. Don't use goop to attach to drywall though. Build standing up with a bit of support just on the bottom. The long slots won't need any support. Drawn in Solidworks.

Adjustable stand for Elektron Octatrack, 0-30 degrees viewing angle.

Illustrator file is ready for submission to RazorLab/Ponoko. Please note, the cutouts for screw mounting are fairly wide to accommodate drafting inaccuracies, you will need to use oversized washers or screws with large heads. The Illustrator file includes a guide layer should you want to improve the accuracy of the design however the actual cutting layer is no longer registered with the guide to make the stand fit within the cutting area. I used 3 mm acrylic and there's a little give left to right so you might want to try 5mm instead although most of the force in operation is front to back so it's not essential.

description.text: A Makerbat redesign to include a attached moon (or mood) ring around the bat. Great for Halloween Jewelry. Use alone for a quick and easy print or snap into it\\'s included moon case. You can turn the bat in it\\'s moon case depending on your mood or as a sign that it\\'s getting late and time to leave the party (see Sleeping Bat pic). Case should be large enough to put in some of your own jewelry or and small LED light.

Print in black, white, or Glow-in-the-Dark abs. use alone (rimmed or non-rimmed version) as a necklace or print out the back plate and case rim in separate colors for contrast. if you want to get fancy put something inside the case. like silver jewelry that looks like clouds like I did, or if you get ambitious an small LED light for back light effect. you can spin the Makerbat in it\\'s moon (or mood) case to whatever you are feeling like or you think looks cool at the time.
Mix and match colors as you like.

description.text: An anatomical model of a human heart, painstakingly assembled from obj files taken from BodyParts3D's database. They claim that I have to say this: "BodyParts3D, Â©  The Database Center for Life Science licensed under CC Attribution-Share Alike 2.1 Japan"

There are a couple errors in the STL mesh that I couldn't seem to get rid of, but it printed just fine. It seems a little larger than life-size, but I'm not really sure; I've never seen a real human heart. With 1:1 scaling this is nearly as big as a Makerbot Replicator would be able to print.
I used ReplicatorG (skeinforge) with raft and support turned on. "Support Minimum Angle" was set to 85 degrees, so it didn't build very much support at all. I also set the "Support Gap Over Perimeter Extrusion Width" to .015 so the support would detach more easily.

title: Prusa i3 X Carriage Adapter for Bulldog XL Extruder

description.text: An X Carriage adapter for the Bulldog XL and Prusa i3 (Aurora design).

It is specially designed so that the E3D fan shroud can still fit in the upright position.
NOTE: I mirrored the Bulldog XL by following a YouTube tutorial.

The servo I'm using is the TGY-1440A. (sub-micro servo)
http://hobbyking.com/hobbyking/store/__7475__Turnigy_1440A_Servo_4_4g_0_8kg_10sec_V2_.html If you don't want to use a servo for the Z probe I have also attached an alternative which utilizes a rubber band snap mechanism. The idea was given to me by a mate.
http://www.thingiverse.com/Aistaca/about The switch is a DM3 micro switch from Jaycar.
http://www.jaycar.com.au/productView.asp?ID=SM1036
Tolerances have already been accounted for so that the Bulldog XL can sit nicely in the mounting grove.
Most of the screws used are M3 x 15mm.
Optional active cooling.
No supports needed!!
This actually increased my printer speed by 1,200%.

NOTE: the stepper cooling fan that can be seen in some of the images can be found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:35436

Print in ABS.
No supports needed!!
You will need:
M3x 15 screws
Cable ties (if you add either Z Probe module)

Since the upper layers of the probe arm (servo version) are very small it is recommended that you print it with other parts of equal or greater height. Short of this, you can print the version with height assistant which will force you printer to move away for a short time every layer.
The snap mechanism version should be ok (unless your printer is insanely fast).

comments.text:
I use Repetier with a RAMPS shield for an Arduino Mega and an E3D hotend. Sorry but i wouldn't know how to answer that question. It's probably something you would want to check forums for.
The servo has power, ground and signal wires. The power had to be connected via a voltage regulator since the servo runs lower than my power supply, ground is ground, and the signal was connected to one of the dedicated servo pins on the RAMPS shield. I switched to the manual rubber band idea because the Repetier software couldn't control the servo and the steppers at the same time without jittering.

comments.text: 1200% ? What was you printing speed, and what is it now? Layer height?
comments.author: madsdyd

comments.text:
My printer was a piece of shit. I was printing PLA at 210 degrees while extruding at roughly 3mm/s. Now I'm extruding at roughly 40mm/s at 190 degrees and I can probably still increase that since I'm not noticing any skipping/slipping.
I have a 0.4mm nozzle and my layer settings are 0.21mm and 0.25mm for the 1st layer. That hasn't changed with the bulldog btw. I'm still playing around with the settings.
One thing I should mention is that it was a MASSIVE pain trying to get the E3D hotend to fit. it still doesn't fit right which means I sometimes get weird lines sticking out of the print where the hotend moved. I just need to find a better way to hold it in.

my first creative test, just a simple pink flower. Printed on Ultimaker 2

Here is my new creation. It is a variation of my iPad stand now made to hold the iPhone.   
The cdr files are for version 15 of CorelDraw. I have also uploaded v13 with the file name extension v13.  
Thanks for all the comments on my other designs. I am looking forward to uploading many more this upcoming semester.  
This was designed at Golden West College at the Industrial Design Department using a laser cutter and engraver.

Use .118 acrylic or polycarb in the same range. If you choose to make thicker make sure to adjust for the tolerances.  
I will upload some more files later but there is the main design in .ai and the .cdr files are for Corell and ready to print on their form.

I am a fan of these small puck shaped cheese disks so I decided to print a stacking holder for them.
These cheeses come in a pack of 6 so I made this tall enough for that.
My printer was not tall enough to print it in one shot so I divided it into 2 pieces that can easily be glued together.
I originally designed it to hold them with the cellophane in place but after I made it I found my next batch of cheese would not fit as well, there were variations on the cellophane wrapper.
So instead just remove the cellophane and put the bits in with just their wax shell on.

I printed this with a pretty heavy infill of 85%. This made sure it was sturdy and has a little weight to it.
Just print both, assemble as shown, stack cheese inside and pull out one piece at a time from the bottom opening.

This is used to hang a book by it's spine. It's rather specific to an installation I'm doing but figured I'd put it here anyways.

comments.text: Sorry, it's a bit hard to describe. Like I said in the description, it was pretty specific to a window installation we were doing. I've added 2 more photos so you can look at how they were used. A small hole is drilled in the exact center of the binding and mono-filament is run through it and tied to this support. Four corners of the open book are also attached with mono-filament and tied around some of the pages. Up top, the center support is on an arm that moves up and down, and the corners are tied in at fixed points. It causes the book to appear to flap when a motor is run.

author: tgloor

title: Hex test part with center hole

description.text: I was able to get my MakerBot printing the square test parts fine, but when I printed this, I realized that much more tuning was needed. I'm not sure how to tune the MakerBot using this part, but I know it would help, since the default settings make several very obvious errors with it, such as burying the nozzle in the plastic during the upper layers.

Print it, If it comes out perfect with no blobs, Great! if not (which is the more likely outcome) you have more tuning to do. I'm currently messing around with layer height and feed-rates, as well as temperatures, and I'm pretty sure that once this part prints perfectly, I'll have a pretty amazingly tuned MakerBot :-)
It's also an extremely small part, and doesn't really need a raft, so it takes very little time to print, and very little material.
if anyone has success printing this really nicely, or using it to tune their MakerBot, Post a comment and I'll be happy to post what settings this was useful in tuning!

comments.text: I know exactly what's going on. Your "Extrusion width over thickness" in Carve is too low. Skeinforge thinks that the lines are thinner than they actually are and thinks it can squeeze in a little bit of infill. Turn up this ratio, bit by bit, until there is no more blobbing.

A replica of the racing light tree

Design the tree itself, making sure everything is connected and the size that you want. Cut holes into each light place the size of an LED light. Print two of this template on an acrylic laser and glue them on top of each other. Place an LED light into each hole and light them up with a method best fit for you. Design a base and add two sides to it, to make your tree stand.

Sometimes, during the design of a device, you have to add one or more cooling fans.
Because the fans should be able to blow air to / from the external environment, you need to drill holes on the surface of the case that you are going to draw.
There are normally two options:
1- Drill a trivial circular hole of diameter slightly less than that of the fan impeller, providing the necessary lateral holes to hook a protection grid
2- Drill a set of many, small holes or slits (for the passage of air) directly on the body of the case, thus avoiding having to create the holes to mount the protective grid, and the use of the grid itself.
Of course, both for reasons of cost and assembly, the 2nd solution is often preferable.
The following OpenSCAD script allows you to generate just the "negative" of these holes / slits.
It constructs a series of parametric solid objects, which can then be used to "pierce" the surface of the case you are going to design.
For more details and examples, see http://ninjacross.com/Modules/Kms/Public/Kms_View.aspx?KmsItemCode=kmi_0000000000000000048 For a similar project, see http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:476061

1- Open the script using OpenSCAD
2- Customize the variables on the top part of the script
3- Generate/render the model.
4- Export the model in STL, or another format compatible with your CAD software, like this http://ninjacross.com/public/ContentItems/it-IT.rci_0635459658880156250/Concentric_Holes_38_5_3_2_Height50.png
5- Intersect the generated model with the surfaces you want to cut/drill, like here http://ninjacross.com/public/ContentItems/it-IT.rci_0635459658880156250/WithHolesGenerators.png
6- Once intersected, remove both the generated model, and the cutted parts from you original case/object, like here http://ninjacross.com/public/ContentItems/it-IT.rci_0635459658880156250/WithHoles.png

title: Multirotor flightcontroller adapter 45mm to 30mm (NanoWii, Naze32 etc.)

description.text:
My quadcopter frame has holes spaced at 45 mm to accomodate most of the flightcontrollers. This was a bit of a problem for me since I am using relatively small boards such as NanoWii and Naze32.  
So I created these small adapters to be able to mount those small flight controllers on larger multirotor frames.  
The NanoWii version is for flightcontrollers that have 30mm spacing and the Naze32 version is for 30.5mm spacing.  
If there is interest I will try to make a customizer version.
Use M3 (nylon) screws, nuts and/or pillars to install. Holes may need to be drilled to fit the screws.

author: CasualSpy51

description.text: kpi

Rob (tinkerings) asked me to make a crystal spool for his crystal Cupcake and I thought that I'd try to make a few improvements to:
  • Make the spindle easier to load and disassemble.
  • Improve the coupling in between the spindles and between the spindle and the bot.
  • Try to prevent binding by keeping the filament from getting under the the spool.
    • I've made the spindle case keyed so they lock together when stacked. I've also added a top tray that the Cupcake sits on that is keyed as well and has slots for the bolt heads on the side of the bot. You can pop the tray off easily to get to the spool, and the top of the spool is secured by a single M5 bolt so it's easy to disassemble to reload. I've also added some PETG fingers around the base of the spool in an attempt to prevent the filament from getting under the spool and binding.

Construction is pretty similar to the original and is pretty straight forward.  The PETG fingers are a little experimental at this point, and since the spool isn't any bigger than the stock one, you won't be able to throw a full 5lb roll on it with them installed.

description.text:
Modelo topográfico del monte Matterhorn en la frontera entre Italia y Suiza. Creado a partir de datos ASTER GLOBAL DEM descargados desde:
http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/
Los datos están disponibles en malla de 1 segundo de arco (aproximadamente 30m en el ecuador).
Para la obtención del modelo STL, se ha usado DEMto3d, una herramienta útil y fácil de usar para covertir MDE (modelos digitales de elevaciones) en modelos STL, listos para imprimir en 3D. DEMto3D está disponible en la siguiente dirección: http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D funciona como una extensión disponibles para los softwares SIG gratuitos Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) y QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

Topography model of the Matterhorn in Switzerland. Created from ASTER GLOBAL DEM data downloaded from http://earthexplorer.usgs.gov/
The data are posted on a 1 arc-second (approximately 30–m at the equator) grid.
To obtain the STL model, I used DEMto3d, an easy and useful tool to convert DEM data to STL models ready to print. This tool is available in the next link http://www.demto3d.com/
DEMto3D is a plugin available for free GIS software Kosmo (http://www.opengis.es/) and QGIS (http://www.qgis.org/en/site/)

comments.text: Great model and I really like this workflow. I gave it a shot and was only able to create a bunch of perfectly flat .stl files :) I downloaded the "ASTER GLOBAL DEM" data from USGS. I get a zip archive that has 2 .tif files (one xxxx_num.tif and xxxx_dem.tif). I loaded the dem.tif into kosmo and tried DEMto3D with the entire area of the data (and smaller areas). spacing .2 and 1:10 (gives 100mm by 100mm .stl). Always perfectly flat.  Also tried the num file and a ton of other stuff. Any ideas?
comments.author: mies

comments.text: Now DEMto3D v2.1 supports DEM input in geographic coordinates (latitude and longitude)!!!!. All you have to do is select the correct projection at the beginning of Kosmo, i.e. EPSG: 4326 for the reference system WGS84.
comments.author: mies

comments.text:
The terrain model is in xxx_dem.tif file. The problem is that you should reproyect the layer from geographical coordinate (lat º, long º) to another system in meters as UTM. To do this I use the software Global Mapper since Kosmo are working on it. Another option is to find another provider of DEM data which use UTM coordinates.
You could send me the file and I will back you the right file.
comments.author: mies

comments.text: Thanks Jawensi. This is all very new to me :) I'm going to play around with this more over the weekend. I'd like to eventually put some models up in here also.

Halloween is that one magical time of year when each individual looks deep into there own phychi and finds the person they really wish they were. And then, for one day, you get to dress as that person without anyone mocking you. This year I looked at my Halloween preparations and found something missing, MINIONS!!! How Can Anyone Be Respected Without MINIONS!!! Rise My Little Spider Pumpkins! Bring Your Terror Upon The World With Dopey Glowing Eyes Of Doom! But I have so little time, and there is so much world. There is only one way. I must harness the power of Amateur Distributed Manufacturing to quickly spread my Minions to the farthest corners of the globe! I Call Upon You My Brothers and Sisters of 3d Printing! Make a Spider Pumpkin Of DOOM! And Release It Upon The Unsuspecting World!

You will find 8 holes on the underside of the body. Six are for the legs, two for the arms. Or if you want to change it up, that's good to. While printing, make the legs and arms from pieces stiff 1/16" wire, dry cleaning hangers work great. I'll leave exact design of the arms and legs up to you. Variety, after all, is the spice of life Glue the Legs into the Body and the Pincers onto the Arms. Drop in a LED/3V battery combination and put on the top. Finaly, Upload a picture of my newly created minion so we can all Observe In Growing Terror as the Furry of the Spider Pumpkins Spreads! The Body is a derivative of Colehard's pumpkin,
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4470
I would like to thank Colehard for providing such a well modeled pumpkin. Because of his contribution, this thing went from drunken conversation to printed item in one afternoon.

description.text: This case is for the Arduino Esplora board. It includes a bezel for use with the Adafruit 1.8" display. It has clear windows with light guides for the RGB LED and light sensor, and tubes to guide sound to/from the beeper and mic. All the buttons including reset are brought up to the case top.

• Print the Bottom, Top, Buttons, Bezel, and LightGuides STL files at .3mm layer height, 50% fill, 0 extra shells. I recomend PLA for the Top and Bottom to minimize shrinkage issues. You may want to use support for the Top.stl file because of the tabs on the switch pushrods.

  • Print the Windows.stl file using clear PLA at .3mm layer height, 100% fill, 0 extra shells.

  • Glue the connector cover to the case bottom. It goes in the slot in the back all the way down with the thinner side up so the top case can go inside it. (I recoment test fitting everything together before gluing anything)

  • Put the windows in the holes over the light sensor and the LEDs. They should be a tight fit and not need any glue. You may need to trim them to fit. I find that putting them in smooth side out looks best.

  • Put the switch pushrods (the round things with the tabs on the side) into the holes in the top over the switches. They go with the tabs to the bottom. Make sure the slide freely. Glue the button tops onto the pushrods.

  • Install the Esplora board into the case bottom. It is attached with #2 x 3/16 screws.
    • steps 7 and 8 are for using the display:

  • Plug the display onto the Esplora board. I used two extra connector pins with the top halfs cut down to the plastic to support the other side of the display.

  • Put the case top on the case bottom. Line up the display bezel over the display and tape it in place on the case. Take off the top and glue the bezel in from the back.

  • Put the reset pushrod into the hole in the top over the reset switch. Make sure it slides freely.

  • Put the case top onto the bottom. Do this with the top and bottom upright so the reset pushrod does not fall out of the top.
    • Parts list:
  • Arduino Esplora board: Currently only avalible at Radio Shack. Online or in a store.
  • Display: Adafruit 1.8" display. http://www.adafruit.com/products/358
  • 2 x 3/16 sheet meatal screws: J&R Hobby hardware. http://www.jrhobbyhardware.com/shop/index.php?main_page=product_info&cPath=122&products_id=315

description.text: A minimalistic x carriage for use with a Bowden extruder and a J Head on a Prusa Mendel

Update 2/6/13
I was made aware of the size issue with the M4 Nut in the 1.75mm X Carriage. I uploaded a new file to correct this. Required Items:
2x M3 x 30 Screws (25mm should work)
2x M3 x 16 Screws
4x M3 Nuts
M3 Washers
2x LM8UU Bearings
4x Ziplocks
Parts for a Bowden 1) Print
2)Clean up, there are multiple holes that need to be cleaned.
3)Insert nuts in their respective nut traps. It is suggested to super glue the belt clamp nuts in.
4)Insert the Bowden tube, and it's nut, then the J Head
5)Clamp the J Head in place with the clamp and 2 M3 x 30 screws
6)Insert the LM8UU Bearings, then zip lock in place
7) Place on axis. There are 2 different carriages, one for 1.75mm filament and 3.00mm Filament I am using this in conjunction with Chowderhead's Belt Terminator (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31482) so only one belt clamp is required.

comments.text: Unfortunately decreasing the number of the linear bearings makes the carriage bend not perpendicular to the axes... there should be one more bearing on the belt side

A fixed Drive block only for flexible filament, made for Makerbot The Replicator. It makes sure the filament is tightly supported below the feed mechanism together with a modified M6 tube (PTFE tube inside). Ball bearing 11x5x5. I developed this filament feeder to be used with my own TPU filament, letting the filament do it´s own pressure against the drive-wheel. Please also check out my unuiqe UV-stable, flexible and conductive filament called ETPU 95-250 Carbon Black filament. Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

Two types of diffusers to fit onto the Canon Speedlight 580EX II flash. I made these for our photographer at MAKE and they've been holding up even after several weeks of daily use.
The triangular version maximizes surface area for greater light diffusion. 
The rectangular version is smaller but can be slid down the flash to make it compact and portable. 
Both have a tight slide fit that allows the diffuser to be adjusted up or down the flash.
Autodesk Inventor file included.

For the rectangular version, the attached Cura profile have good settings to start with.
For the triangular version, change to have zero bottom layers and zero infill. I suggest 0.1 to 0.2 mm layer resolution, single wall/shell/parameter, and using the Joris setting in Cura. The Joris setting makes the wall as a single continuous spiral, resulting in a very strong part. Note: The triangular version might form a slit at the very top since it is rounded, making the top only one or two layers of solid infill (depending on your layer thickness). Flash performance is still great/not affected by it though. I used 2-year-old MakerBot clear PLA on an Ultimaker to print these.

description.text:
A grape / wine press with a volume of just over 11 litres.
Customisable via the openSCAD files, use different sizes of planks for the barrel, a different number of planks etc
A 3d printer enabled project as some woodwork required!
In use the 12mm threaded rod through the center has locknuts top and bottom. there is a captive nut on the top paddle. Rotating the threaded rod, with a big bar, screws the top paddle down and compresses the grapes. The bottom paddle is held in place by 3 bottom retainers, it (and the compressed cake) can be removed by rotating the base.

As built the wine press uses:
Barrel:
13 planks of 4.4x1.8x30cm planks
3 planks 4.4x1.8x35cm planks (for the legs)
10 barrel support.stl
3 bottom stop.stl
Paddles:
18mm ply (this was just for speed you could probably make something that looks / works better)
Top paddle includes top_nut_trap assembly (top nut trap.stl, M12 nut, M12 repair washer - the nut is a tight fit, I put mine in the freezer before tapping it in place)
Centre Rod:
M12 x 60cm
2 nuts and M12 repair washer for the bottom
2 nuts for the top

comments.text: I only used the press once. I had a bumper crop of grapes and I really wanted to make some wine. The wine turned out fine but the grapes are white and I really only drink red, so now I just eat the grapes! If I were to update it: I'd change the way the bottom attaches, maybe with some over centre latches, when the grapes are compressed in getting it apart was quite difficult. I'd also use a lead screw rather than a threaded rod. The threaded rod just adds too much resistance and limits the pressure you can generate, I had to press the grapes in quite small batches. I did learn that to pres grapes you really need to "tread" them first, the skins need to be split before they go in the press.

comments.text: I used PLA. Be sure to print with at least 3 shells to ensure the parts are strong and importantly waterproof for cleaning. A couple of observations when using the wine press, the triangular thread of the M12 screw presents a lot of resistance when applying significant pressure, idally you'd replace it with a trapezoidal or square thread but at the very least ensure the grapes are well crushed / trodden before you put them in the press. I also found the cake difficult to get out after pressing, I'd make more clearance in the bottom plate and possibly wrap the grapes in a muslin next time. If you build one I'd be interested to hear your experience.

author: Palmiga

title: Single-Perimeter Rocket for Seamless Spiral Printing

description.text:
This rocket is roughly similar to a V2 design, but with a single perimeter that allows you to use the spiral vase option in Slic3r to eliminate the seams. 3D Maker Noob does comparison print of three printers using the rocket:
https://youtu.be/NiJPAq2Z0so?t=14m52s Check out the 15x by 19x print of this rocket at the Midwest RepRap Festival: https://twitter.com/pdp7/status/711716330899116032 3D Printing Nerd prints a 24-inch rocket here: https://youtu.be/Rk_0AS3XCbs?t=2m19s Niklas Ramström prints an 800mm rocket here:
https://youtu.be/mCKW5WEwDvA

Rotate the model in Slic3r so the rocket is upright for printing. The example was printed on an Orion with 1.75mm T-Glase, using .6mm nozzle setting (actual nozzle is .5mm), .5mm layer height, .6mm extrusion width, 10mm/s speed, spiral vase mode, zero infill, vertical shells perimeters (min) = 1, 220 degrees temp on the extruder, 60 degrees on bed.
When you print with T-Glase this way, it is fairly transparent because it is hollow with walls that are .6mm thick. If not rescaled, the rocket is about 5.5 inches tall.
With .5mm layer height, this model is only sturdy enough to be a display model, not a flyable rocket. Any defect that occurs while printing becomes a weak area where the layers can separate if stressed.
You can print it at .2 mm layer height to get more strength, but it loses a lot of it's transparency. Or you can print it with more vertical shell perimeters, but you then have to turn off the spiral vase mode and you get visible seams where it changes Z.
If the tip ends up a bit wiggly, it can easily be straightened up with an x-acto knife.
UPDATE: 4/6/2015 - Added RocketForMegaScaling.stl. This fixes an issue some people had where scaling the rocket to larger sizes would cause Slic3r to create a tiny cylinder along the axis of the upper part of the rocket.

comments.text: The rocket body is made by taking a 2-D outline and rotating it 360.  This seems to create a thin axis for some slicer programs, so I added a solid cylinder along the axis, but only along part of the length of the rocket.  This filled in the axis so that a zero-percent infill would eliminate the phantom axis, but I have never printed it at 250%.   So, tell me, in what portion of the rocket did the axis appear, upper or lower?
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text:
Lower part. I did some manipulations with surfaces in S3D and the axis seemed to disappear. But that was after I printed the thing, so the lower part printed a bit worse.
Also, the rocket body is somewhat low-poly when upscaled to 250% and higher.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: Try RocketForMegaScaling that I just added.  I made the cylinder larger.   I can't do anything about the low poly as the original outline was coarse.
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text: OK, no axis even at 500%. Thanks!
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: If I had it to do over again, instead of making a longitudinal outline and rotating it to make the solid body, I would probably make a series of cross-section circles and use the loft function in FreeCad, as that would make for a smoother body. That is how I did the rocket plane (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:492176) . That seems to result in much smoother curves that are scalable.
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text: If I had it to do over again, instead of making a longitudinal outline and rotating it to make the solid body, I would probably make a series of cross-section circles and use the loft function in FreeCad,
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: I just made a similar rocket 700mm long in Fusion 360. I used revolve to create the body and it's really smooth. But I had to set very low export tolerances to get a smooth STL model... 134K triangles. I'll try to print it one of these days and then probably share it.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: It's just a matter of export parameters. Mine vs yours http://i.imgur.com/Bo9WXUL.png
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text: Can you tell me what parameters you changed?
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text:
Sure. Fusion 360 has a lot of parameters, I just seriously decreased everything http://i.imgur.com/PyTRNFm.png
Some settings produced visually smooth STL, but slicing shows artifacts. Not sure if it's a problem of Fusion or slicer.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: I think the cylinder I added only extends through the top half because that is where the problem was without upscaling.  Sometime today I will lengthen it to cover the whole rocket, and I will export it using finer tessellation so it will scale better.  Stay tuned.
comments.author: pkmcnc

comments.text: Love it - very cool model, "RocketForScaling.stl" printed really well with 0.3 mm layer vase setting on Slic3r/Repetier on my hacked Da Vinci. I increase the flowrate by 25% for vases to add a little bit to the width of the walls for strength.
comments.author: MatthewGTaylor

comments.text: it's not only perimeter...slic3r do it full ...why?
comments.author: mangiafuoco99

comments.text: Choose the spiral vase option,  and set the number of perimeters to 1.
comments.author: mangiafuoco99

comments.text: Thank you so much and sorry for the question but I'm not very experienced because I have my printer from just 1 week.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: No problem!   Click the Instructions tab above, and you will see all the settings.
comments.author: mangiafuoco99

comments.text: Anyone is able to scale it ? When I scale it at 200% it starts trying to do a 'square' inside shape at about 120mm high... .I'm using slic3r to slice.. If I scale it in netfabb or slic3r it does the same thing... (200% or 600%) but I cannot see it in slic3r...Do you have an idea ?
comments.author: lyncos

comments.text: Try the RocketForScaling.stl file that I just added.
comments.author: lyncos

comments.text: Very nice model. I also had problems for the fins: Simplify 3D and Cura draw them separately and they are barely touching at the top. Due to that problem, the object isn't really printed in vase mode, as the head has to travel between fins and the body. Does your original model have this separation between the body and fins?
comments.author: drmaestro

comments.text: Slic3r generates a continuous path so the fins are firmly attached.  You might try adjusting your extrusion width to a smaller value.  Or scale it up slightly and see what your slicer programs do with it.
comments.author: drmaestro

comments.text: Tried with Slic3r. It works. Thanks.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: hopefully one day my prusa will complete prints like this... :-(
comments.author: Henk_i3

comments.text: Check out audin's Candy-Filled Rocket remix: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:591805
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: I LOVE this.  For real.  This is beautiful!
comments.author: Blacklight1880

comments.text: Yeah, I just tried Kisslicer, and it looks like the vase option causes it to travel from body to fin, without any extrusion in-between.  I don't see any obvious fix for it, but I am not an expert on Kisslicer.  Slic3r makes a continuous spiral loop that includes body and fins, extruding all the way, so it is one solid piece.
comments.author: mechg

comments.text: Just made one.  When I sliced it with Kisslicer, using the vase option for infill, it worked and looks great, but the fins are barely attached to the body.  I'm sure there's a setting I'm missing to make it fixed to the frame better, but I don't know what it is.

Don´t need the conductivity? Well the conductivity is great for some things but perhaps not your first choice? Then consider this: This filament will give you some really nice benefits if the conductivity is not an disadvantage for your 3D printed design: •The material composition eliminates “stringing / webbing” issues.
•The hardness of 95 shore A and the carbon black filler makes for great print abilities.
•The carbon black filler is an excellent UV stabilizer thus the prints are built to last in very harsh environments.
•The matte black surface finish has a very exclusive look.
•The material feels very nice and dry to touch.
•It´s not too stretchy and will do great for timing belts etc. http://rubber3dprinting.com/

author: monicalindberg

description.text:
A case for Openpilot's OPLink Mini telemetry modem  
! for old modems with angled antenna connector !  
2014-05-27: oplink_rework__v03, reversed antenna direction

The main body barely fits in the CupCake build area-- I had to rotate it 45 degrees to squeeze it in. This bot can be assembled from some pretty common items, standard servos, 6xAA battery pack and an Arduino. (See the second shape pack.) It\'s not really a \"printable robot\" in the sense that I\'m still requiring pretty complex parts (even making the common \"circuit exception\" used by the RepRap foundation in their builds), BUT there\'s no custom machining to do once you print the parts out. Just print \'em, slap on the mail-order parts and you\'ve got a bot. You\'ll also need screws and nuts to hold things together, at whatever size works for your area. I\'m using 4-40 screws but anything that\'ll fit a 3-mm diameter hole will do.
This is a protective case with a lid for the iPhone credit card reader from Square.

Print it out.
You may need to file the inside so that the reader does not fit too snugly.

description.text: Want to add slick transparent side panels to your Replicator 2 like those on the 2X?  Just print 4 of these clips for each side and cut yourself some polycarbonate sheet.  They'll snap firmly in place but are easily removed when necessary.  Good for reducing drafts and dust in your build area.

For each side panel you'll need four of these clips and a piece of 1/16" thick polycarbonate (or other material) measuring 8.25" x 7". I printed the clips from Makerware using the High resolution setting but specified 30% infill, 1 shell, and 0.2mm layer height.
The narrower slot is for the new 1/16" panel material. The wider slot will fit over the Replicator 2's PVC side panel along the inside of the side windows.
Fit two clips each on the top and bottom edges of your new side panel. Slip the upper edge into place first and press the lower edge into position. The lower clips will snap into place.

description.text:
This one has a really nice star shaped base. And a lot of strings! The droopier one reminds me of a spider web. If not for the hole in the base it could be a decent pen/pencil holder. This Thing was designed with the filament's tendency to droop in mind. Those thin rings in the model should print as single sagging filaments. I designed and printed with 0.3mm layers, but I imagine a little bit larger or smaller should work. The first print I did was white PLA at 205 degrees. It drooped a little more than I wanted, so I printed it again at 190 degrees. But that one didn't droop at all! I think both look nice. I will have to try again at around 200 degrees though. I am not sure how much it will droop in ABS, give it a try. Make sure to turn support off! Dimensions:
77.5mm x 73.8mm x 81.6mm tall

description.text: Another biohazard symbol but this one is different from others on Thingiverse because the positive is not all one piece. It is meant to be combined with the negative and printed with 2 different colors on a dual-extruder setup. Overall diameter of negative medallion is 1.50" (38.10mm) x 0.25" (6.35mm) thick. Positive biohazard symbol is 0.10" (2.54mm) thick.

Drawn from scratch while looking at biohazard pic. I have not tried printing this yet as I am in the middle of building my first bot. If you print it, let me know how it goes. Trying to dust off my drafting education in the meantime.
This will probably make a good calibration piece for a dual-extruder setup. Pretty much all arcs.
P.S. If you print just the positive, you will have a biohazard symbol in 6 pieces. Might be some cool artistic possibilities there.

description.text:
Make your own Stephen Colbert shot glasses out of ice!
Print at 1x scale for ice cubes, and 1.5x scale for shot glasses. I recommend at least 0.8mm shell thickness and 110% extrusion rate to prevent leaks.
Attach the Front and Back sections and hold them together with a large rubber-band (or tape). Fill with water, and then put the top piece on. Excess water will flow out of an over-flow channel, so do this over a sink.
Throw it in the freezer, and wait. I recommend your beverages be at least chilled, or else these shot glasses may melt too quickly. (I am not liable for any property damage caused by melting or broken shot glasses)
Made with Blender.

Disclaimer: This item is a projectile so please use safely and do not point at any person. Use in an open clear area.

comments.text: Hi Bart, I've all wired up an tight and can't really look up the colour combination oft the wires. As far as I understand the nema technic you can wire any colour together as long as they belong to the same coil. You can recognize the different coils due to the position oft the wires , they can be devided into two pairs, one pair for each coil. Also you can meassure the resistance with a DMM. If you got a low resistance than you've found one pair of wires of one coil. The other two wires automatically belong to the second coil. Now wire that up.  If the nema spins in the wrong direction simply change the Position of the 2 wires from one coil e.g. if u have brown on blue and red on yello switch them to brown on yello and blue on red. Hope that helps.
comments.author: BTjr

Over 90,000 different combinations to choose from.
  • Including 8 standard cars (you can mix and mash these to form over 100 combinations)
  • one of 3 optional spoiler.
  • Front facing weapons.
  • Change wheel size and rim design
  • Change the overal length of your car to turn a pickup into an extended cab or create a limo.
    • This is the beginning of a larger concept, as I get more experience with OpenSCAD I will update the models (and add some more) to make them look better

This OpenSCAD will take a very long time to process so please be patient.
The models have not been tested yet aside from basic testing to ensure they should generate valid STL code.
Leave a comment with details of any problem you have and I will fix the code ASAP.
Wheel size, affects the sizing of the wheel wells so if you want to be able to hot swap wheels, choose the largest wheel sizes.
There are several options for build platform. The intent is for this model to be fabricated from 3 colors/materials (tires, tire rims, and body)

description.text:
This is a model of a U.S. Quarter, as dimensionally accurate as possible. Have fun!
If you like my designs, let me know with a little bitcoin:
16QaNzCAGKhyjAtwPhy9WxNk8NRhzw8rk7

Print this out in two halves (provided). This is sized exactly to the dimensions of a real quarter, but feel free to scale it up in your favorite slicing program so you can flip it for the big decisions in your life!
You can print it and try to trick vending machines, but it probably won't work as most vending machines detect metal.

comments.text: With few exceptions, existing law generally prohibits the manufacture, sale or use of any token, disk or device in the likeness or similitude of any coins of the United States, or of any foreign country, which are issued as money.
